fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, when starting a build in Bamboo (either manually or through triggers), the build is automatically associated with the HEAD at the time the build is put in the queue, i.e. the build is executed with the latest version of the files in the repository at the time the build is triggered.

On busy systems, a long time may pass between the time a build is queued and when it is actually executed. This in turn means that there may be more commits to the repository before the build starts, however these commits are ignored since the version of the repository to build with was already determined when the build was first queued.

While this may work in most situations, there are circumstances where this behaviour is not desirable and where it would be more efficient and sensible for a build to be run against the latest version of the repository at the time when the build is actually starting, regardless of which version was in the repository when the build was queued.

h3. Suggested Solution

A configurable option should be provided (potentially on the plan level) to allow administrators to determine which policy to use (HEAD at time of queuing or HEAD at time of execution).
 
h3. Workaround

There is currently no known workaround.
fields.summary: As an administrator I want to be able to configure whether the latest version in the repository is selected at queue time or execution time

h3. Problem Definition
Customers may have security policies that require strict control of user access to linked repositories. Bamboo does not allow the permissions of a linked repository to be set during the creation process, nor the ability to change the default permissions, so newly created repositories are visible to all logged in users upon creation.

h3.
h3. Suggested Solution
Change the default permissions for newly created repositories so that "logged in users" is unchecked by default

h3.
h3. Workaround
At present users must immediately correct permissions after creating linked repositories and must also review the creation of all linked repositories to ensure the correct permissions have been set by other admins
fields.summary: Disallow logged in users permissions for new Linked Repositories by default

fields.description:
Build result pages of failed runs of a particular plan were loading in about 30 seconds. Almost all of this time was being spent under {{com.atlassian.bamboo.resultsummary.tests.TestsManagerImpl.getTestsForChainResultByDeltaState}}, even though the results of the corresponding SQL query were small and arrived in no time.  It turned out that after performing this query, Hibernate was eagerly loading all TEST_CASE rows, current and historical, and the latter in this patological case (due to user error) was in hundreds of thousands.

The solution was to edit {{com/atlassian/bamboo/resultsummary/TestResults.hbm.xml}} in {{atlassian-bamboo-persistence}} jar and replace {{lazy="false"}} with {{lazy="true"}} (since the default in this file is {{lazy="false"}}) from the relation between TEST_CLASS and TEST_CASE.  I do not see where loading all of the TEST_CASEs may be a good idea, and Bamboo does not seem to load them on its own.
fields.summary: TEST_CLASS table should enable lazy loading of TEST_CASE entries

{code}

I found that publishing artifacts is a bottleneck in our process. It takes from 21 to 23 minutes to publish artifacts from a remote agent. The total artifact size is 2.7G, amist 25 files and 6 distinct artifact groups.

When we switched to doing this process from a local-agent, we found that it takes only 1 to 2 minutes.

Our jobs are simple. They grab all the artifacts from plan X, and repackage them to itself. I found I didn't need to do that on a remote-agent, so I created a local-agent on the Bamboo server. I was floored to discover how much faster that was.

FYI, the remote agents were connected to the local LAN, over (at least) 1Gb/s connections. Also, the artifact-download part of this task was very quick, < 20sec(?). The data clearly indicated it was the artifact-publish part that was the bottleneck.
fields.summary: Publishing an artifact from a remote agent takes 20x longer than local agent

fields.description:
h1. Problem situation
This is a general idea/thoughtrain - based on our CI plans we run with JIRA/Bitbucket/confluence/Bamboo. 

Consider 2 applications (we actually have 10), on different Bitbucket repositories (not all have CI git-branches but that's irrelevant). There is one plan which builds all the artifacts of the different applications (all this is fine). The result is a set of artifacts to create a Release with for Deployment.
The deployment is split up in environments: Integration, Test, Acceptance, Production. The deployment happens with a set of tasks - irrelevant which they are. Now the issue is that Bamboo holds no concept of "sites" or "application". Unless I split up the deployment projects in "Integration application A", "Integration appliciation B", ... Of course we don't want that (we generally deploy everything in one go due to dependencies between de applications).
At the moment we wrote a plugin which lets us select "applications". It translates it into a variable and updates the variable of the Environnment when de deploy is started.

h1. Proposed solution
A Deployment Project (object), should be able to hold some simple metadata which defines the applications that live on this Environment. (At the moment we abuse a comma-seperated variable for this). When a Deployment is started and the applications are defined, you can select which "applications" are to deployed to this environment. Technically - Bamboo could reuse the concept of the VariableContext and create a special type of Variable for this. Generally also allowing a "custom run" if users which to specifiy other variable.

h1. Integration with JIRA
JIRA already integrates with Bamboo - and tells us which Environments have been deployed to. When transitioning issues - we could also query the list of Applications from Bamboo and "check" the applications. This can than be used at the end of spring to create a list of applications that need to deployment.
This is a common problem - where developers don't generally know what to deploy at the end of the release process (so people end up deploying everything).
At the end of the Agile sprint. When a version is released - the version will propose the list of the applications to be deployed - based on the checkboxes selected in all the jira issues of this sprint.
(At the moment we abuse a custom field and a tagcloud to see which applications have to be deployed).

h1.CI summary
# I handle an issue in JIRA, when transitioning an issue and applications are defined in Bamboo environments, I can select them
# When releasing a version in JIRA - I can see the list of applications impacted by all issues in the sprint
# I can specify a list of applications (if they are defined in Bamboo) when I start a deploy - so a variable is passed to the Deployment where I can act on these applications.
fields.summary: Deployments should contains a concept of "sites" or "applications"

I am evaluating Bamboo and followed the instructions at 

https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/running-bamboo-as-a-linux-service-416056046.html

First of all, most major Linux distributions have switched to systemd. You may want to update your code to support that. SysVinit will be going away.

Secondly, the initscript on that page doesn't work as is.

The script relies on BAMBOO_HOME, but that is not set in the script.

The convention on Debian/Ubuntu would be to put such environment config in, e.g., /etc/default/bamboo and sourcing that file from the initscript, so that the initscript can remain untouched and identical on different installations.

Furthermore, I noticed that the script does not stop bamboo properly. I had lots of "hanging" java processes which I had to kill -15 manually.

Please consider the OS provided infrastructure for starting and stopping services. There are tons of examples out there how to spawn a process, capture its pid and ensure only one instance is running if the application is a singleton. (look for start-stop-daemon)

In the long run, I would expect proper Debian/Ubuntu (and CentOS/RHEL) packages that take care of a) installing dependencies like the JRE or an RDBMS like PostgreSQL b) creating users, c) creating a database user and database, d) proper integration into systemd, ... 

There is no point why sysadmins should do copy-paste installs, when these steps can be perfectly coded as scripts for each particular platform. That way, the installation process can be automatically tested using CI...

Just my 5c as a sysadmin who installs Bamboo for the first time.

h2. Summary
Currently, there is no straightforward information on how to estimate the amount of connection required by Bamboo.

h3. 1. From Atlassian's documentation
{panel:title=Example: How to estimate the number of db connections}
The following formula gives a rough estimate of the number of database connections that will be required:
{code}
(Concurrent users)/5 + (Busy remote agents)/5 + (Local agents)*1.1 + (Amount of concurrent change detections)
{code}
For example, an instance with:
* 5 concurrent users
* 30 busy remote (or elastic) agents
* 30 busy local agents
* 60 plans with repository polling set to 60 second intervals (assume 3 seconds per change detection)
\\ 
would require 1 + 6 + 33 + 3 = 43 connections.

Bamboo ships with a pre-configured connection limit, however this can be modified by editing the following value in your bamboo.cfg.xml file:
{code:xml|title=<bamboo-home>/bamboo.cfg.xml}
<property name="hibernate.c3p0.max_size">100</property>
{code}
{panel}
Please, refer to [Database connection pool size|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/bamboo-best-practice-system-requirements-388401170.html#BambooBestPractice-SystemRequirements-Databaseconnectionpoolsize] for further information.

h3. 2. Based on Atlassian's documentation
h4. 2.1. How to get some values from Bamboo's database
h5. Concurrent users
Assuming the worst case scenario in which is the amount of users from Bamboo internal directory and External users available to Bamboo.
{code:sql}
/* Get users from Bamboo internal directory */
select count (*) 
  from users;
{code}
{code:sql}
/* Get external users (JIRA/Crowd/Active Directory) */
select count (*)
  from external_entities;
{code}
h5. Remote agents or Elastic agents
{code:sql}
/* Get Remote agents */
select count (*) 
  from queue 
 where agent_type = 'REMOTE'
{code}
Bamboo reads the Elastic "{{Region}}" set up under "{{Bamboo administration >> Overview >> Elastic Bamboo >> Configuration}}" from "{{<bamboo-home>/xml-data/configuration/administration.xml}}"
{code:xml|title=<bamboo-home>/xml-data/configuration/administration.xml}
<region>US_EAST_1</region>
{code}
And use this value to get the Elastic agents available by running the following query:
{code:sql}
/* Get Elastic agents */
 select *
  from elastic_image 
 where region = 'US_EAST_1'
{code}
h5. Local agents
{code:sql}
/* Get Local agents */
select count (*) 
  from queue 
 where agent_type = 'LOCAL'
{code}
h5. 'Repository polling' or 'Scheduled'
{code:sql}select  B.FULL_KEY as PLAN_KEY, 
        B.TITLE as BRANCH,
        VL.XML_DEFINITION_DATA as REPOSITORY,
        BD.XML_DEFINITION_DATA as TRIGGER_TYPE
   from VCS_LOCATION as VL
   join PLAN_VCS_LOCATION as PVL 
        on PVL.VCS_LOCATION_ID = VL.VCS_LOCATION_ID
   join BUILD as B 
        on PVL.PLAN_ID = B.BUILD_ID
   join BUILD_DEFINITION as BD
        on B.BUILD_ID = BD.BUILD_ID
  where
        BD.XML_DEFINITION_DATA like '%Repository polling%'
     or
        BD.XML_DEFINITION_DATA like '%Scheduled%'
{code}
As a response from the query above, you will have under "{{TRIGGER_TYPE}}" column something similar to the following XML structure.
{code:xml|title=TRIGGER_TYPE}
<!-- Repository polling -->
<buildStrategy>
	<config>
        <item>
			<key>repository.change.poll.pollingPeriod</key>
			<value>VALUE</value>
        </item>
	</config>
</buildStrategy>

<!-- Scheduled -->
<buildStrategy>
	<config>
        <item>
			<key>repository.change.poll.cronExpression</key>
			<value>0 0 0 ? * *</value>
        </item>
	</config>
</buildStrategy>
{code}

h3. 3. Informartion in Bamboo Support Zip
When generating Bamboo Support Zip under "{{Bamboo Administration >> System >> Atlassian Support Tools >> Support Zip >> Create}}" we can find the following information:
{code:xml|title=Bamboo Support Zip >> application-config >> application.xml}
<statistics-information>
    <index-time>929</index-time>
    <number-of-plans>725</number-of-plans>
    <number-of-results>92730</number-of-results>
</statistics-information>
...
<max-local-agents>-1</max-local-agents>
<max-remote-agents>0</max-remote-agents>
<max-users>0</max-users>
<max-plans>10</max-plans>
{code}

h3. 4. Expected
Since the Bamboo Support Zip is a tool to provide information about users' instances, the same should provide either
* the amount of database connection poll required by the instance
* the parameters required by the formula above presented
fields.summary: How to estimate number of Database Connection Pool

fields.description:
h3. Bamboo is special because of (kinda important to know / understand )
First of all, i really like Bamboo and the most important *USP* compared to Hudson (any other) is the Release and Deploy Integration.
Not only keeping track of what got released, comparing those and having proper artifacts, it also helps maintaining different environments and levels of deployment, e.g. before it reaches market A, customer EAP or just the whole public.

We do release our software (different ones, including a jira and conlfuence plugin, but also C++, JRuby, Ruby, PHP an more) using the release numbers in bamboo. This is a very important thing to us, since this reflects back in jira issues and tells everybody, when it has been released. Not only internally this is a very important thing to know, but also during customer support and questions like “do i already have this fix / feature?”. Not to speak about the changelog feature we can simply generate.
Therefore we do not use a different version-system for the software we ship to the customer, we use only the one in bamboo so we can talk about exactly the same releases in the public, in jira, in the support, in the docs, support and marketing - just everywhere.

This is an important fact to understand to actually see what we miss - and you actually offer by 90% ( and no other software ). 

h3. How we use Bamboo
Build and test in build0tasks by design - generating build-artifacts (jars, tars, whatever)
This happens on every commit, all day long - as it is supposed to be with CI
When we decide to release a build, we
# a) *important*: create a release-version in Bamboo for this build
# b) *important*: We HACK the “first environment” to build a *release* artifact, lets say a 'maven based jar', based on the release-vesion, which is ONLY available in the deploy-task and thus in this missued environment 
# c) *important* : the PSEUDO artifact created in b) is checked in into a project-based “release artifact” repo - a hack for every projet
 We use all other environments to deploy to actual environments using the release-repo

As you see, we can't use the build phase due to the absence of the “release version information”, thus we cannot really create a special “release artifact” in the build phase, lets say in a manual stage as supposed by Joshua

Being forced to move this into the deploy tasks (where the release version is available by design), lets you hack every single deploy task, it basically flanks your whole concept of artifacts. And even more important, there are no “deploy artifacts” or say “release artifacts”. So what i described for a-c happens for every single project, a hack by design.

h3. A lot of potential to break
Somebody does not run the pseudo first “build the release task” but rather hits the other releases first -> releases an old version out of the release repo. In addition, if you want to chain environments, you can really do that, since they have no order. So if you chain, it can happen, that the build-the-release-artificat environment runs later, with the issue described above.

h3. But this is not even all of it
recreating the release artifact will lead to *huge* duplication of complex build tasks in every environment. This will make maintenance a nightmare in addition, recreating is a huge waste of ressources and basically no option

What i ask for or what i would like to propose is, why we don’t introduce “release artifacts” and a release task for a deploy-project.
For each deploy project, you define a “release task” which does all the re-building based on the release-version. This artifact is based on the build-artificat - at least with a changed version and maybe “more minimized, obfuscated, concatinated, cleand up, removed debug info…"
during the release-creating, this task is run and will create an release artifact
this artifact can then be used in all deploy-environments for whatever kind of deployments, wherever needed

h3. Alternatives
On the summit, i got told by Joshua, that you inject a version in a manual stage of the build phase and create a special release artifact. Thus you have 2 different versions for a product.

This deletes a lot of other features you have and beside that, that is *the usp* compared to hudson, teamcity / whatever
Releasing in Jira does just create an arbitrary release number nobody cares of. You cannot really talk with the customers about that or relate to that, since the software version (injected in the build phase) differs from the version show in jira (bamboo release version)
releasing from jira does not make any sense
“Release” does not make any sense at all in bamboo, if you flank it with your own versioning-metric which is invisible to bamboo - it should rather then be removed to have at least a clean concept

h3. Too long but still..
I am open to any suggestions or solutions, but as far as discussed with Joshua, this is basically not possible to work-arround. Since you introduced the importance of artifacts, you introduced the release linkage and comparision in jira and bamboo, you released huge new features based of versions in jira with jira-software, you should now really think about the importance of this version in bamboo and the consequences.

I would really love to see this “versions” becoming that huge, as you implemented them in jira and artifacts as important as you did in bamboo .Thanks!

Defining a local server executable capability
Local server capabilities are inherited by all local agents. This means that local agents can all make use of the executables installed on the Bamboo server machine.
Before you begin:
If you want to run multiple Maven agents on your local server, you will need to configure repository isolation for your Maven executables. See Configuring repository isolation for Maven executables for details.
To define a new local server executable capability:
Click the  icon in the Bamboo header and choose Overview.
Click Server Capabilities in the left navigation panel.
Choose Capability Type > Executable in the 'Add Capability' section at the end of the page.
Select the appropriate type of executable from the Type list.
In the Executable Label field, type a name/label for the executable, which Bamboo presents in the Executable list whenever a Task's executable is configured.
In the Path field, type the appropriate path. This will depend on the Type you selected in the previous step.
Note that for Ant and Maven, Bamboo requires the path to be the location of the executable installation folder.
Click Add.

Please see the video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MYyaqUWrK8Y&feature=youtu.be
